Article title: Tracking New vs. Modified Records in EDL Updates
Article subtitle: Using first_seen_date to identify new records in data deliveries
Article body: For Enterprise Data License (EDL) customers receiving monthly data overwrites, tracking whether a record is new versus pre-existing and modified can be accomplished using the first_seen_date field in the PERMITS table. While there isn't a specific change flag in the current data schema, this timestamp indicates when Shovels first discovered the permit in our data collection process. By comparing first_seen_date with your previous data delivery, you can identify new records where the first_seen_date falls after your last update. For modifications to existing records, you'll need to implement a comparison between the current and previous data deliveries, focusing on fields like status, valuation, or other attributes that might change over time. This approach requires maintaining a copy of previous deliveries for comparison purposes. We're actively working on enhancing our data delivery system to include explicit change tracking flags in future releases, which will simplify this process for customers who need to monitor specific changes in the permit landscape.

Article title: Shovels' Key Differentiators
Article subtitle: What sets Shovels apart from competitors in the permit data space
Article body: Shovels differentiates itself through several key factors: 1) Very clean data - addresses are standardized to USPS format and geotagged with coordinates; 2) Comprehensive contractor data derived directly from permit metadata, including contractor grouping that links contractors under the same parent organization; 3) Modern data infrastructure using AI and machine learning, with a documented 98% accuracy validated by construction industry experts; 4) Sophisticated deduplication that maintains a unique identifier for each permit and updates records as permit statuses change, rather than creating duplicate entries.

Article title: Tracking Multiple Permits at a Single Property
Article subtitle: How Shovels tracks and links multiple permits at the same location
Article body: We use a system of unique IDs to track multiple permits at a single property. Each permit gets a unique permit ID that remains persistent throughout its lifecycle. Each address gets a unique address ID the first time it appears, allowing you to easily find and connect all permits at that location. Each contractor gets a unique contractor ID when they first appear on any permit. These IDs act as reference points that allow you to track and join related permits, addresses, and contractors in our database.

Article title: What is a Jurisdiction?
Article subtitle: Understanding the governmental entities that issue permits
Article body:
In the context of Shovels data, a jurisdiction refers to the Authority Having Jurisdiction (AHJ) - the governmental body responsible for issuing building permits in a specific geographic area. This is typically either a county or a city government. Jurisdictions play a crucial role in the construction permitting process as they establish and enforce building codes, conduct inspections, and maintain official records of construction activities. Nationwide, there are approximately 20,000 different jurisdictions, each with their own specific requirements, processes, and data formats. Shovels has standardized data from over 1,400 jurisdictions, covering approximately 80% of the US population. Understanding which jurisdiction governs a particular property is essential for contractors and service providers, as it determines which rules apply and which office must approve permits. Shovels maintains a comprehensive list of all jurisdictions we cover, which is available on our blog.

Learn more: https://www.shovels.ai/blog/ahj-in-construction/

Article title: Regional Variations in Contractor Data Coverage
Article subtitle: There are differences is coverage by US geographical region
Article body: Shovels' contractor data includes whatever information is provided on the permits themselves, with coverage quality varying by region. We have strong coverage on the West Coast, in New York, and in certain areas of the Midwest. However, coverage in Upstate New York is not as comprehensive. Massachusetts presents challenges due to its township structure, where permit data and contractor details aren't always readily available online. Similarly, New Jersey has limitations because the state doesn't typically include contractor data on permits. These regional variations reflect the different reporting requirements and data availability across jurisdictions.

Article title: State and Zip Code Validation in Address Searches
Article subtitle: Understanding address search behavior with incorrect location parameters
Article body: When using Shovels' API for address searches, it's important to understand that state and zip code parameters are not validated as part of geo_id resolution. If you provide an incorrect state or zip code when searching for addresses, you won't receive an explicit error message. Instead, the API will return an empty result set (null items), indicating no matching address was found. This behavior is by design to accommodate variations in how addresses might be recorded across different jurisdictions. For the most reliable results, we recommend providing as accurate address information as possible, particularly focusing on street name, number, and city. If you're consistently getting empty results for addresses you believe should exist in our system, double-check that you're using the correct state and zip code information. Our system uses multiple address verification sources including the National Address Dataset, Open Address dataset, Simple Maps, and ESRI to ensure the highest possible accuracy in address matching.

Article title: Handling Errors with geo_id
Article subtitle: Managing invalid geolocation IDs in API requests
Article body: When working with Shovels' API, proper handling of geo_id errors is essential for smooth application performance. If you provide an invalid geo_id when querying permits, you'll typically receive a 422 Unprocessable Entity response with the message: "Invalid geolocation ID value. Have you resolved your address into Shovels geolocation ID?" This indicates that the geo_id format is incorrect or hasn't been properly obtained through our address resolution endpoint. However, it's important to note that if the format of the geo_id is technically valid but doesn't correspond to any known address or permit in our system, you won't receive an error. Instead, the response will contain no results (an empty items array with a 200 OK status). To avoid these issues, always begin your workflow by resolving addresses through our Address Search API before attempting to query permits with the resulting geo_id. Implementing proper error handling in your application for both 422 responses and empty result sets will improve user experience and help troubleshoot integration issues.

Article title: Source of Coordinate Data
Article subtitle: How Shovels determines the geographic coordinates for addresses
Article body: The latitude and longitude coordinates in our data are geocoded addresses. This geocoding process is done in-house at Shovels to ensure accuracy and consistency across our database.

Article title: Tracking Multiple Permits on the Same Property
Article subtitle: How our ID system connects related permits at the same location
Article body: Shovels uses a robust system of unique IDs to track multiple permits at a single property. Each permit receives a unique permit ID that remains consistent throughout its lifecycle, from application to completion. Each address gets a unique address ID the first time it appears in our system, allowing you to easily connect all permits associated with that location. Similarly, each contractor receives a unique contractor ID when they first appear on any permit. These IDs act as reference points (foreign keys) that enable you to track and join related permits, addresses, and contractors in our database. For example, you can use the address ID to find all permits associated with a specific property, even if the address is written differently across different permits. This system is particularly valuable for tracking property improvements over time, identifying contractors who frequently work at the same location, or analyzing permitting patterns for specific properties. Our consistent ID system makes it simple to build relationships between different data points, enabling sophisticated analysis of construction activity.

Article title: Complete List of Jurisdictions
Article subtitle: Where to find our complete list of covered jurisdictions
Article body: Yes, Shovels maintains a comprehensive list of all building permit jurisdictions we cover. This list is publicly available on our blog at https://www.shovels.ai/blog/list-of-all-building-permit-jurisdictions/. The list includes approximately 2,000 jurisdictions, representing about 85% of the US population. Each jurisdiction is an Authority Having Jurisdiction (AHJ) - typically a county or city government responsible for issuing building permits in its area. Our coverage continues to expand, with 10-30 new jurisdictions added each month. The jurisdictions we cover follow a power law distribution: about 15% of jurisdictions represent approximately 85% of the US population, while the remaining 85% of jurisdictions cover just 15% of the population. This is why we prioritize larger jurisdictions while continuously expanding into smaller ones. The jurisdiction list is regularly updated as we add new coverage areas, so checking the link periodically will provide the most current information on our geographic coverage.

Article title: Shovels' Mailing Address
Article subtitle: Shovels' official mailing address for correspondence
Article body: Shovels' official mailing address is 3515 Mt. Diablo Blvd, Unit #51, Lafayette, CA 94549.

Article title: Assessing Contractor Quality Through Data
Article subtitle: Using data metrics to evaluate contractor quality and performance
Article body: Shovels evaluates contractors based on objective data points, including the quantity of permits pulled, jurisdictional coverage, and timeframes for permit completion. These metrics can serve as indicators of a contractor's quality - for example, their experience level (how many times they've done similar work), their familiarity with specific cities, and their efficiency (how quickly they complete jobs). While Shovels focuses on these quantitative data points, customers often supplement this information with qualitative feedback from sources like Google reviews, Yelp, Thumbtack, and word-of-mouth recommendations to form a more complete picture of contractor quality.
Keywords: completion times,contractor quality,performance metrics,contractor assessment,permit volume

Article title: How Monthly EDL Data Deliveries Work
Article subtitle: Understanding the replacement model for enterprise data deliveries
Article body: For Enterprise Data License (EDL) customers, Shovels employs an overwrite approach when pushing data into data lakes such as Snowflake, Databricks, or BigQuery. Each monthly delivery is treated as a fresh table, completely replacing the previous month's data with the updated dataset. This approach simplifies data management by eliminating the need to merge incremental updates. Importantly, our permit IDs, address IDs, and contractor IDs remain static and don't change from release to release. This consistency ensures that any scripts, analyses, or processes that rely on these IDs won't be impacted by the monthly refresh. The stability of our ID system allows customers to build reliable data pipelines and maintain referential integrity in their analyses. Each monthly delivery includes all historical data plus new permits and updates, providing a complete and current view of the construction permitting landscape. For customers who need to track changes between deliveries, we recommend using the first_seen_date field in combination with status change indicators to identify new and updated records since the previous delivery.

Article title: Searching for Permits
Article subtitle: Using geo_id to retrieve permit data effectively
Article body: To search for permits in the Shovels API, you'll need to use the geo_id parameter, which serves as the unique identifier linking addresses to their associated permit data. The process follows these steps: First, use our Address Search endpoint (https://api.shovels.ai/v2/addresses/search) to find the address of interest. When the address is found, you'll receive a geo_id in the response. Then, use this geo_id to query our permits search endpoint, which will return all permits associated with that location. The geo_id system offers several advantages over direct address searching: it ensures consistent identification regardless of address formatting variations, provides a stable reference point even if address details change over time, and improves query performance. Our permit search endpoint supports additional filters including date ranges, permit types, and contractor information, allowing you to narrow results to precisely the permits you need. This two-step process of address resolution followed by permit querying ensures accurate results and optimal API performance.

Article title: Understanding Shovels' Resident Data
Article subtitle: How Shovels assembles and validates resident demographic data
Article body: Shovels' resident data features like gender, age_range, and income_range come from multiple non-LinkedIn sources. We assemble data about individuals via common linkages between a person's name, workplace, personal address, and business or personal contact information. Our data compilation process uses consensus and observation date methodology to select the most likely and current data points for each individual. The data includes both directly observed information and modeled/probabilistic data. For complete details on our data schema, you can refer to our Universal Schema documentation.
Keywords: data sources,personal information,demographic information,data compilation,resident data

Article title: Source of Latitude and Longitude Data
Article subtitle: How Shovels generates accurate location coordinates
Article body: The latitude and longitude coordinates in Shovels' data are derived from our proprietary geocoding process. Rather than relying on a single third-party service, we perform this geocoding ourselves using multiple reference sources to ensure accuracy. Our process cross-references addresses against several authoritative datasets including the National Address Dataset from the US Census, the Open Address dataset, Simple Maps, and ESRI. This multi-source approach allows us to achieve higher accuracy rates than depending on any single geocoding service. Accurate geocoding is particularly important in the construction industry, where precise location information can impact everything from permit jurisdiction to zoning requirements. These coordinates enable our customers to perform spatial analysis, create map visualizations, calculate distances, and identify geographic patterns in construction activity. The geocoding process is part of our broader address standardization pipeline, which ensures consistent formatting and accurate location data across our entire database, regardless of how addresses may have been formatted in the original permit records.

Article title: The Data Labeling and Annotation Process
Article subtitle: How Shovels ensures accuracy in permit classification
Article body: Shovels employs a rigorous data labeling and annotation process to ensure high-quality, accurately classified permit data. Our approach involves multiple independent annotators labeling each record, with manual review and resolution in cases where their responses diverge. The validation sample size is proportionate to the representation of each category within the total dataset, typically including between 1-5% of the overall data to ensure adequate validation points for every category. A key aspect of our methodology is having annotators independently solve the task rather than validating model outputs. This prevents annotator bias and creates a "golden dataset" of correct answers that can be used to benchmark any new model outputs across iterations without requiring fresh human validation each time. This approach has proven particularly effective for accurately classifying permit descriptions, which often contain industry-specific terminology, abbreviations, and inconsistent formatting. Our case study on using specialist participants for data labeling (available on our blog) details how we achieved 98% accuracy in our classifications by incorporating a panel of experts from the construction industry.

Article title: Permits Without Addresses
Article subtitle: How Shovels handles permits for properties without official addresses
Article body: Yes, Shovels does capture permits that don't have an associated address. This situation commonly occurs with newly subdivided parcels or undeveloped land where construction needs to begin before an official address is assigned by the post office. In these cases, Shovels assigns a unique permit ID to track the permit, but there won't be an associated address ID, physical address, or geographic identifiers such as county, city, or jurisdiction codes. The only geo-identifiers included with these address-less permits will be state and jurisdiction information. These permits are still valuable data points as they often represent new construction projects at their earliest stages. For users interested in new development opportunities, these permits can provide early intelligence about upcoming construction activity. As the project progresses and an official address is assigned, we update our records to link the permit with its new address, allowing for continuous tracking throughout the construction lifecycle. This approach ensures we don't miss important permit activity, even when traditional address-based identification isn't possible.

Article title: Data Annotation and Validation Process
Article subtitle: How Shovels ensures high-quality data through annotation and validation
Article body: Our data annotation process involves multiple independent annotators labeling each record. When their responses diverge, we manually review and resolve the discrepancies. The validation sample size is proportionate to each category's representation in the dataset (1-5% of overall data). To avoid bias, annotators independently solve tasks rather than validating model outputs. This approach creates a "golden dataset" of correct answers that can benchmark any new model outputs across iterations without requiring new validation rounds.

Article title: How Individual Permits are Created and Tracked
Article subtitle: Understanding how permits are uniquely identified and updated
Article body: Each permit in the Shovels database receives a unique permit ID that remains persistent throughout its entire lifecycle. As updates are made to the permit - such as status changes, valuation adjustments, or contractor assignments - we update the data while maintaining the same permit ID. This approach ensures a continuous record of the permit's progression without creating duplicate entries. The permit lifecycle typically flows through several stages: filing (status: in_review), approval (status: active), and completion (status: final). If a permit is abandoned or revoked, its status changes to inactive. For each status change, we update the corresponding date fields (file_date, issued_date, final_date) while maintaining the same unique identifier. This consistency allows users to track a permit's complete history without having to piece together fragments across multiple records. Our deduplication process ensures that even when jurisdictions report the same permit multiple times with different statuses, Shovels presents a single, up-to-date record with the most current information.

Article title: Why Flat Files Cost More Than API Access
Article subtitle: The features that make flat file deliveries more premium than API access
Article body: Flat file deliveries command a higher price point than API access for several compelling reasons: they contain significantly more data fields, eliminate latency issues, enable complex SQL joins and queries, provide superior support for data science applications, and can include additional datasets like tax assessor files. Furthermore, flat files make it much easier to get complete monthly updates and track differences between time periods - a process that's considerably more challenging when using an API.

Article title: Resolving Addresses
Article subtitle: The critical first step in accessing permit data through the API
Article body: Address resolution is the essential first step in using Shovels' API effectively. Always begin by resolving the address through our Address Search API endpoint: https://api.shovels.ai/v2/addresses/search. This endpoint searches for addresses that are associated with permits in our system and returns standardized address information along with a unique geo_id. The geo_id serves as the key to unlocking permit data in subsequent API calls. If you query an address that doesn't have any associated permits in our database, the API will return a 200 OK response with an empty items array, indicating the address was understood but no permit data exists. For optimal results, provide as much address information as possible in your query, including street number, street name, city, state, and ZIP code. Our system uses multiple verification sources to standardize addresses, ensuring consistent results even when input formats vary. This standardization process is particularly valuable in the construction industry, where address formatting can be inconsistent across different jurisdictions and permit applications.

Article title: Error Handling for Geo ID Queries
Article subtitle: Understanding and handling geo_id errors in API requests
Article body: If you provide an invalid geo_id when querying permits, you'll typically receive a 422 Unprocessable Entity response with the message: "Invalid geolocation ID value. Have you resolved your address into Shovels geolocation ID?" Note that if the format is technically valid but doesn't correspond to any known address or permit, you'll receive no error but the response will contain no results.

Article title: Tracking New vs. Modified Records in EDL
Article subtitle: How to distinguish between new and modified records in monthly data deliveries
Article body: Currently, there is no specific flag indicating changes in the records. However, there is a first_seen_date in the PERMITS table which could be used to determine whether a record is new or pre-existing.
Keywords: record tracking,data management,first seen date,data changes

Article title: The "is_representative" Field Meaning
Article subtitle: Understanding contractor group representation in data deliveries
Article body: In Shovels' Enterprise Data License (EDL) deliveries, the "is_representative" field serves an important function in understanding contractor relationships. This boolean field indicates whether a particular contractor record is the main representative of a contractor group_id. The group_id is a unique identifier that links together multiple contractors operating under the same parent organization. When is_representative=TRUE, that contractor record contains the canonical or preferred information for the entire group. This feature is particularly valuable for enterprise customers analyzing large contractor datasets, as it helps prevent double-counting of organizations that operate under multiple names or licenses. For example, a national HVAC company might pull permits under regional subsidiaries, but our grouping algorithm identifies these relationships and designates one record as the representative. This enables more accurate market analysis and prevents reaching out to the same organization multiple times under different names.

Article title: Identifying Independent Contractors
Article subtitle: Reliable methods to identify sole proprietors and individual contractors
Article body: Identifying independent contractors (ICs) in the Shovels API can be accomplished in several ways. The most reliable method is through the biz_type field, though it has limited coverage across our dataset. As a practical heuristic, if a business name appears to be a person's name (e.g., "John Smith" rather than "Smith Construction"), it often indicates an independent contractor. Other signals that may suggest an independent contractor include: having only a single contact person across all permits, a low permit volume compared to larger firms, and absence of multiple employee records. Independent contractors typically represent a significant portion of the contracting ecosystem, especially in specialized trades like electrical work or plumbing. Understanding which contractors are independent professionals versus larger companies allows for more tailored marketing approaches and helps in accurate market segmentation for products or services targeting the construction industry.

Article title: Contractor Address Information Availability
Article subtitle: Full USPS addresses available through API responses
Article body: Shovels provides complete USPS-standardized addresses for contractors when available through our API responses. This includes street address, city, state, ZIP code, and in many cases unit or suite numbers. Our addresses undergo rigorous verification against multiple sources including the National Address Dataset from the US Census, Open Address dataset, Simple Maps, and ESRI. This multi-source verification ensures the highest possible accuracy for contractor location data. The standardized format makes it easy to integrate with mapping services, CRM systems, or marketing platforms. For enterprise customers using our EDL service, these addresses are delivered in a consistent format that requires minimal cleaning before use in your data pipeline.

Article title: Historical Data Coverage
Article subtitle: How far back Shovels' historical permit data extends
Article body: Shovels' data coverage extends back to at least 2010 for all jurisdictions, with many jurisdictions offering data that goes even further back. This timeframe was a technical architecture decision based on the majority of our customers' feedback and use cases. It's worth noting that in some cases, jurisdictions don't pull historical data into their online systems, which can limit how far back certain records go. However, our coverage of the past decade provides sufficient historical context for most analysis needs.

Article title: Difference Between Permit Search and Contractor Search
Article subtitle: The different results returned by permit versus contractor searches
Article body: Permit search returns permits that were pulled on specific addresses in the geographic area you searched. Contractor search returns B2B contact information, license data, and classification data about the contractors who pulled those permits. It's important to note that not every permit will have an associated contractor. This depends on whether the county/city requires the permit application to include contractor information, and also on whether the contractor chooses to provide this information when applying.

Article title: Differences Between Primary Phone and Phone Fields
Article subtitle: How Shovels organizes and prioritizes contractor phone numbers
Article body: Shovels differentiates between two important phone number fields in our data: primary_phone and phone. The primary_phone field displays the most frequently used phone number across all permits for a specific contractor, giving you the highest probability contact number for reaching the business. The phone field, on the other hand, provides a comma-separated list of all phone numbers we've encountered for that contractor, ordered by frequency of use. This comprehensive approach gives you both a prioritized main contact number and alternative options if needed. For example, if a contractor has used three different phone numbers across their permit history, with one appearing on 70% of permits and the others on 15% each, the most common number would be designated as the primary_phone, while all three would be listed in the phone field. This dual approach maximizes your chances of successful contractor outreach.

Article title: NAICS, SIC, and Industry Classification Data
Article subtitle: Understanding the sources and limitations of industry classification data
Article body: Business industry classifications come from self-reported data, typically through registration or insurance-related transactions. These classifications are quite broad, and companies in higher-risk occupations often use multiple industry identifiers to reduce their workers' compensation insurance liability. There is no central authority governing these categories, so the Primary_industry field should be taken with a grain of salt. NAICS codes are a more modern and specific version of SIC codes, but not as widely adopted, which is why both are included in the data.

Article title: Understanding the "Homeowner" Field in the Residents Table
Article subtitle: How the probabilistic homeowner data is determined and validated
Article body: The probabilistic homeowner feature in Shovels' residents data is sourced from our data co-op members and represents a consensus-driven determination of property ownership. This data feature is compiled through multiple validation methods to ensure reliability: Consensus: We require 3+ different data signals to confirm data linkages, with reliability ensured through exhaustive validation methods and confirmation from actual usage. For example, the presence of a unit number is considered as part of this compilation. Conformation: This process ensures that data within the "Consensus" realm not only represents frequent occurrences but also adheres to proper formatting and data standards, and cannot be invalidated using existing signals. We also offer additional features in our "Consumer Attributes" dataset that includes information such as "number of kids," "grandparent in household," etc. Users can also leverage other available features like "income range," "children," and "net worth" to identify trends that could help determine homeownership likelihood at certain demographic levels.

Article title: How Filters Work in Shovels Online
Article subtitle: Understanding the current limitations of permit counting with filters
Article body: When using filters in Shovels Online, it's important to understand how the system processes and displays contractor data. The platform shows contractors based on permits pulled within your specified timeframe and meeting your filter criteria. However, users should note that the count of permits displayed alongside each contractor remains static regardless of the filters applied. This means if a contractor has pulled 100 permits total but only 10 meet your current filter criteria, the platform will still show "100 permits" next to their name. We recognize this can be potentially misleading and are working on implementing a dynamic counting system that adjusts according to the applied filters. In the meantime, users can click into individual contractor profiles to see the detailed breakdown of permits that match specific criteria. This functionality is particularly useful for identifying contractors who specialize in certain project types or work in specific geographic areas, even if the count doesn't automatically update with filter changes.

Article title: Job Titles for Contractor Contacts
Article subtitle: Accessing job titles across Shovels products
Article body: Yes, Shovels provides job titles for contractor contacts across all our product offerings. In the API, job titles are available through the employees endpoint, though coverage varies as this information isn't always included in public permit records. For Shovels Online users, you can access job titles by clicking into contractor profiles, where employee information is displayed with their respective roles when available. EDL customers can receive job titles as part of custom reports, with an example available in our documentation. Job titles help you identify decision-makers within contracting companies, allowing for more targeted outreach. Common titles in our database include Owner, Project Manager, Office Manager, and various trade-specific roles like Master Electrician or General Contractor. This information is particularly valuable for sales teams who need to reach specific roles within contracting businesses.

Article title: Residential vs. Commercial Permit Distribution
Article subtitle: The breakdown of residential versus commercial permits in Shovels' data
Article body: Shovels' data includes permits across all asset classes, with a broad distribution of approximately 60% residential permits and 40% commercial permits. This comprehensive coverage ensures that customers have access to permit data across the full spectrum of construction and renovation activities.

Article title: Data Refresh Frequency and Volume
Article subtitle: How often Shovels updates its data and the volume of new information
Article body: Shovels currently refreshes data twice a month, on the 1st and 15th. Nationwide, we add between 5-10 million new records to the dataset each month, along with 1-5 million status updates to existing records. When a permit status or other data field changes, the jurisdiction updates it in their platform, which allows us to access it. We then clean up the data, incorporate it into our system, and release the updates on the 1st and 15th.
Keywords: data volume,status updates,new records,update frequency,data refresh

Article title: Size of Data Files
Article subtitle: Expected file size for Shovels data deliveries
Article body: Shovels data is typically delivered as 15-20 GB of Parquet files, optimized for efficient data processing and analysis in modern data environments.

Article title: How Shovels Verifies Data Accuracy
Article subtitle: The methods Shovels uses to ensure data accuracy and reliability
Article body: Shovels verifies data accuracy through multiple external sources. For address standardization, we cross-reference details using four different address sources: the National Address Dataset from the US Census, the Open Address dataset, Simple Maps, and ESRI. For contractor verification, we match contractor information against publicly available state license files, ensuring that the contractors in our database are properly licensed and legitimate operators in their respective fields.

Article title: Contact Names and Emails Discrepancy
Article subtitle: Understanding the relationship between contact names and primary emails
Article body: When working with Shovels data, you may notice that contact names and email addresses don't always align perfectly. This is because our system captures data differently for these two fields. Contact names are specific to individual permits and represent the name provided on that particular permit application. However, primary_email addresses are determined by analyzing frequency across all permits for a given contractor. For example, if John Smith is listed as the contact on a specific permit, but jane.doe@company.com appears most frequently across all of that contractor's permits, the primary_email field will show Jane's email rather than John's. This approach ensures you have the most actively used contact point for the company, which increases the likelihood of successful communication. For customers needing person-specific email matching, we recommend using our advanced contractor profiles which provide more granular employee contact information when available.

Article title: Filtering Contractors by Company Size
Article subtitle: How to use employee count ranges in the API
Article body: The Shovels API provides comprehensive data about contractors, including their company size. When querying our contractor endpoints, you'll receive employee count ranges in the response payload, which allows you to filter contractors based on specific size requirements. For example, you might want to target only small businesses with fewer than 10 employees, or perhaps you're looking for enterprise-level contractors with 100+ employees. Our size classifications are determined through multiple data points, including business registrations, permit frequency, and other proprietary indicators to ensure accuracy. This feature is particularly useful for sales teams who need to segment their outreach based on company size.

Article title: Geographic Coverage and Jurisdiction Distribution
Article subtitle: How Shovels prioritizes geographic coverage across jurisdictions
Article body: Shovels' coverage follows a power law distribution across the approximately 20,000 jurisdictions in the United States. About 85% of the US population resides in just 15% of jurisdictions, and Shovels has strategically focused on covering these high-density areas first. Currently, we cover approximately 2,000 jurisdictions, representing about 85% of the US population. We continue to expand our coverage, adding 10-30 new jurisdictions and 5-10 million new permits each month. While we're still working on covering the "long tail" of smaller jurisdictions, our current coverage already encompasses the majority of America's population centers.

Article title: What counts as an API request?
Article subtitle: New accounts on Shovels receive 250 free API requests to explore our capabilities before committing to a paid plan. This article explains what constitutes an API request so you can maximize the value of those 250 pings.
Article body:
Every HTTP call you make to the Shovels API—no matter which endpoint you hit—deducts 1 request from the 250-request starter quota that comes with new accounts. This applies to the search endpoints (GET /v2/permits/search, GET /v2/contractors/search) and to the detail endpoints (GET /v2/permits, GET /v2/contractors).

How many records can one request return
You can ask for up to 100 permits or contractors in a single call by setting the size (or limit) parameter to 100. Whether you retrieve 1 record or 100, it is still just one request against your quota.

Detail already included in search results
Search responses contain the full detail payload for every record returned, so you usually don’t need a separate detail call. If you do call a detail endpoint—whether for one ID or many IDs—it still counts as only one request.

Practical examples
• GET /v2/permits/search?size=100 → 1 request
• GET /v2/permits?id=123 → 1 request
• GET /v2/contractors/search?size=100 → 1 request
• GET /v2/contractors?id=abc,def,ghi → 1 request

Each of these cases consumes exactly one of your 250 free pings. 

Note that the same request usage applies when you're on a paid plan!

Article title: How do I find a contractor's service area?
Article subtitle: Use the Shovels API to identify all cities and zip codes where a contractor has worked by analyzing their permit history
Article body:
Understanding where contractors operate is crucial for expanding coverage to lesser-served regions. Rather than relying on self-reported service areas, you can use a contractor's actual permit history to map their complete service footprint across cities and zip codes.

Overview

The Shovels API provides access to permit and contractor data, allowing you to programmatically access building permit and contractor information. The API offers access to two primary objects: Permits and Contractors, with permits being official documents issued by city or county authorities required before commencing construction or alterations to a building.

How It Works

To determine a contractor's service area, you'll analyze their permit history to create a unique list of cities and zip codes where they've worked. This approach provides concrete evidence of their actual operating territories rather than claimed service areas.

API Authentication

Authentication is required for any API request that you make, whether it's in the API Playground or in your own scripts. We use a simple header-based authentication method, X-API-Key: YOUR_API_KEY_HERE. This is available in your Profile Settings > API Key.

Step-by-Step Process

Step 1: Get Permits for a Contractor

Use the /v2/permits/search endpoint to retrieve permits for a specific contractor using the contractor_id parameter. In cases where the required field is a value, like a specific contractor_id or address_id, then it's mandatory to first retrieve the foundational data point before getting the insights for it.

 
bash
curl -X GET \
  'https://api.shovels.ai/v2/permits/search?contractor_id=YOUR_CONTRACTOR_ID&permit_from=2022-01-01&permit_to=2024-12-31' \
  -H 'X-API-Key: YOUR_API_KEY_HERE'

Step 2: Extract Geographic Data

The response includes a wealth of information about each permit including jurisdiction and location details. From each permit record, extract:

  • City/jurisdiction names
  • Zip codes
  • Any additional geographic identifiers

Step 3: Create Unique Lists

Process the permit data to create deduplicated lists of:

  • All cities where the contractor has worked
  • All zip codes in their service area
  • Geographic coverage patterns over time

Understanding Permit Data Structure

The response includes information about each permit including description, number, jurisdiction, property_type, tags, and other relevant data. The current version of the API is v2, which is reflected in the endpoints URL structure: /v2/.

Geographic Filtering Capabilities

The new geo_id system enables precise searching by address, zip code, jurisdiction, city, and county - making location-based queries more powerful than ever. With the brand new geo_id schema, we can expand our search capabilities to a broader capacity, now including counties and jurisdictions.

Best Practices

  1. Use Date Ranges: Generally speaking, the required fields are the start and end dates for the query, and the corresponding geo_id to point the query to the right place. Query recent permit data (last 2-3 years) for active service areas.
  2. Handle Pagination: The API returns data in JSON format, either as pages or single objects. Make sure to handle paginated responses to get complete permit histories.
  3. Filter by Property Type: Use property_type parameters to filter by residential or commercial work to understand different service area patterns.

Shovels Online Alternative

In Shovels Online, we show recent permits for each contractor. You can search for permits and contractors at the county, city, or even specific address level and download permit and contractor data to CSV with a single click.

Additional Resources

For more detailed information about using the API, check out the API Reference tab in the documentation hub which outlines all endpoints, parameters, requirements, and responses. You can also use the /list/* endpoints to get the latest valid values for tags and other filters.

For technical support or questions about implementing this approach, reach out to Support at support@shovels.ai.

Article title: How do I pull contractor employee email information at scale?
Article subtitle: Learn how to use the Shovels API to retrieve contractor employee contact details including business and personal emails, job titles, and seniority levels for targeted outreach.
Article body:
The Shovels API provides a dedicated endpoint to retrieve employee information for specific contractors, including both personal and business email addresses, job titles, and seniority levels. This is particularly useful for identifying key decision-makers like owners, sales directors, and other personnel likely to respond to outreach efforts.

Using the List Contractor Employees Endpoint

The /contractors/{id}/employees endpoint returns comprehensive employee data for a specific contractor. Here's how to use it:

Endpoint: GET /contractors/{id}/employees

Authentication: Include your API key in the header as X-API-Key: YOUR_API_KEY_HERE

Required Parameters:

  • {id} - The contractor ID (path parameter)

Optional Parameters:

  • cursor - For pagination through large result sets
  • page - Page number for offset-based pagination
  • size - Number of items per page (1-100)

Sample Request

 
bash
curl --request GET \
  --url https://api.shovels.ai/v2/contractors/{id}/employees \
  --header 'X-API-Key: YOUR_API_KEY_HERE'

Response Data

The API returns employee records containing:

Contact Information:

  • email - Personal email address
  • business_email - Business email address
  • phone - Phone number
  • linkedin_url - LinkedIn profile

Professional Details:

  • job_title - Current position
  • seniority_level - Senior, Mid, Junior, etc.
  • department - Department or division

Additional Data:

  • name - Full name
  • Address details (street, city, state, zip)
  • Demographics (age range, income range, etc.)

Scaling Your Data Collection

Pagination: The endpoint supports cursor-based pagination for handling large employee lists. Use the next_cursor value from the response to retrieve subsequent pages.

Bulk Processing: To process multiple contractors at scale:

  1. First, obtain contractor IDs using the contractors search endpoints
  2. Iterate through each contractor ID
  3. Call the employees endpoint for each contractor
  4. Implement proper error handling and rate limiting

Targeting Decision Makers: Filter results by seniority_level (Senior, Executive) and job_title to identify owners, sales directors, and other key personnel most likely to respond to outreach.

Best Practices

  • Respect rate limits and avoid frivolous requests
  • Use pagination to handle large datasets efficiently
  • Store and cache results to minimize API calls
  • Filter by job titles and seniority levels to focus on decision-makers
  • Always include proper error handling in your implementation

Getting Started

To begin using this endpoint, you'll need a Shovels API key available in your Profile Settings. The API includes a free trial with 250 requests to help you test the functionality before committing to a paid plan.

Article title: Where do you source your data from?
Article body: We source the data directly from the jurisdictions, either via our relationships with the local governments, or through integration with their online permitting portals.

Article title: Is there a unique identifier for each permit?
Article body: Yes, the unique identifier for each permit is the "ID," which is generated by Shovels and is unique to every permit. This is distinct from "permit_no" which is the permit number assigned by the jurisdiction. There are cases where two different jurisdictions coincidentally assign the same permit_no to two different permits, so the best way to organize the data by unique permit identifiers is the 'ID". See our data dictionary for more of our schema.

Article title: Why do some permit numbers appear to be duplicates?
Article body: Permit numbers may appear as duplicates because they are assigned by the city, and different cities may use the same numbering system. The Shovels ID is used to differentiate between permits from different cities. See our data dictionary for full schema.

Article title: How is the start date and end date defined in the data?
Article body: The start date is the first date recorded for a permit, while the end date is the last date recorded. These date fields are generated by Shovels and help customers understand the timeline of each permit. See this blog post for more information.

Article title: What does it mean if a permit has a final status but no final date?
Article body: If a permit has a final status but no final date, it typically indicates that the permit was issued as an over-the-counter permit, meaning it was approved immediately without the need for a follow-up inspection.

Article title: What format can the data be delivered in?
Article body: The data can be delivered in various formats, including Parquet, CSV, or JSON. The preferred format can be determined based on the team's needs.

Article title: What types of permits are considered over-the-counter permits?
Article body: Over-the-counter permits often include simpler projects like solar installations or plumbing work, which may not require extensive review by the city. However, this can vary by city and county.

Article title: Will there be ongoing support after the initial data delivery?
Article body: Yes, ongoing support can be arranged through regular calls to help interpret and work through the data as needed.

Article title: How are property types and details categorized in the data?
Article body: Property types and details are derived from a tax assessor file, which is included in the data delivery. However, there may be gaps in coverage, and efforts are ongoing to improve this data.

Article title: What documentation proves a contractor's legitimacy and compliance with regulations?
Can Shovels API do fuzzy matching?
Article body:
Address lookup is fuzzy.

Contractor lookup is exact, or you can put in part of the name.

 
For example,  'John Smith Panels' you can search by 'John', 'Joh', 'Sm', 'Panels'

Article title: What data fields are included in permit  downloads?
Article subtitle: Shovels permit record downloads include 40 data fields covering permit details, timelines, property characteristics, and geographic information. Includes permit IDs, job values, approval durations, property valuations, contractor details, and location coordinates.
Article body:
Download a sample

Each record in the permits download represents a single permit application with detailed information spanning the entire permit lifecycle, associated property characteristics, and geographic identifiers.

Key Data Categories

Permit Information The dataset includes core permit details such as unique identifiers, descriptions, permit numbers, jurisdictions, job values, types and subtypes, associated fees, and current status. This provides essential context for understanding the scope and nature of each construction project.

Timeline and Duration Tracking Comprehensive date fields capture the permit journey from initial filing through final completion, including file date, issue date, final date, start date, and end date. Duration metrics track total project time, construction phases, and approval processes, along with inspection pass rates for quality assessment.

Location and Property Details Geographic data includes street addresses, cities, counties, ZIP codes, latitude/longitude coordinates, census tracts, and congressional districts. Property characteristics cover ownership information, assessed market values, lot sizes, building areas, story counts, unit counts, and year built - providing crucial context for market analysis and property valuation.

Additional Metadata The dataset includes contractor IDs for tracking key industry players and tags for flexible categorization and filtering.

Article title: What data fields are included in contractor downloads?
Article subtitle: Comprehensive contractor dataset with 44 data fields covering business details, contact information, performance metrics, licensing status, and project history. Includes revenue estimates, review ratings, job values, permit counts, and inspection pass rates for informed contractor selection.
Article body:
Download a sample

This contractors dataset provides comprehensive contractor intelligence with 1,000 records across 44 data fields. Each record represents a licensed contractor with detailed business information, performance metrics, licensing status, and project history tracked by Shovels.

Key Data Categories

Business Identity and Contact Information The dataset includes contractor identification through unique IDs, license numbers, individual and business names, business types, and classifications. Complete contact details feature primary and secondary phone numbers, email addresses, websites, and full address information including street addresses, cities, ZIP codes, jurisdictions, counties, and geographic coordinates.

Business Intelligence and Market Data Professional profiles include DBA (doing business as) names, SIC and NAICS industry codes, LinkedIn profiles, revenue estimates, employee counts, and primary industry classifications. Customer feedback is captured through review counts and average ratings, providing reputation insights for contractor evaluation.

Performance Metrics and Project History Comprehensive project analytics track average job values, total job values, and permit counts to assess contractor scale and activity levels. Quality indicators include average construction durations and inspection pass rates, enabling performance-based contractor selection and risk assessment.

Licensing and Status Tracking License management data covers issue dates, expiration dates, activation dates, and inactivation dates. Activity status is tracked across multiple states including final, active, unknown, and inactive classifications, with first seen dates establishing contractor tenure in the market.

This contractor intelligence enables users to identify qualified contractors, assess performance history, verify licensing status, and make informed decisions for construction projects and business partnerships.

Article title: What are the key sources you are pulling data from?
Article subtitle: Shovels pulls building permit data primarily from local jurisdictions directly.
Article body:
We gather permit data from a variety of municipal and county government sources across the United States. Our key sources include:

  • Local jurisdiction websites: We collect data directly from city and county building departments' online permit portals
  • Municipal open data portals: Many jurisdictions publish their permit data through dedicated open data initiatives
  • Building department APIs: When available, we connect to official jurisdiction APIs to access permit information
  • Public records requests: For jurisdictions without digital access, we obtain data through formal records requests

We then supplement this permit data with additional information from:

  • State contractor licensing boards: To verify contractor information and licensing status
  • Address standardization databases: We use multiple sources (National Address Dataset from the US Census, Open Address dataset, Simple Maps, and ESRI) to standardize and geocode addresses
  • Tax assessor records: To enhance property information associated with permits

Currently, we cover jurisdictions representing about 80% of the US population, with new jurisdictions being added monthly.

Article title: Where does your data come from?
Article body: We collect the data directly from the cities and counties, either through digital methods, or offline methods such as calling their offices and submitting requests. We don't purchase this data from any other source, and instead get it straight from the source

Article title: What is your pricing structure?
Article body:
For Shovels Online and Shovels API, you can create an account here to see our latest pricing options.

For Enterprise Data options, please contact sales@shovels.ai to talk to someone about your custom needs.

Article title: When is it better to us API vs. EDL or vice versa?
Article body: The API is great for looking up addresses and contractors, product integrations, and local lead lists. If you're trying to get every contractor across multiple counties, and you want all the fields we offer, that's our EDL. We can push this directly into BigQuery, Snowflake, or deliver as parquet files.

Article title: How do I get resident or homeowner email contact information from Shovels?
Article body:
Email contact information can be a bit nuanced, because there are several sources where the contact information will come from, so you'll have to take a look across all of them to see what you can find:
  • APPLICANT_EMAIL from PERMITS table:  If there's an email of the applicant, we will include it here. Sometimes it's the homeowner email, sometimes it's a builder or their contractor (depends on who is applying) - this is EDL only, not in the API
  • OWNER_EMAIL from the PERMITS table: same, this comes from the permit; if it's there, we will include it if someone filled it out (note: if filled, this is the owner email at time of permit submission, so it could have changed depending on how old the permit is) - this is EDL only, not in the API
  • PERSONAL_EMAILS and BUSINESS_EMAIL from the RESIDENTS table. You'll also have to filter for HOMEOWNER = Y on these. If we have data on the residents (aka homeowners') emails, we''ll include in these fields. - this is both EDL and API

For API users, to get the contact info from the RESIDENTS table/endpoint, you need to pass the address_id from the permit object into the residents endpoint. This endpoint will give contact info like name, phone, and email on occupants associated with the address.

Article title: How does Shovels Online work?
Article subtitle: Shovels Online is a powerful tool to help you find building permits and building contractors anywhere in the USA.
Article body:
Dashboard Search Functionality

How does the search function work?

The Shovels dashboard uses an "AND" search logic. This means when you select multiple search criteria, the results will show permits that match ALL selected criteria, not just one or the other.

Can I search by specific keywords?

Yes, you can search by description keywords. This is particularly useful when looking for specific brand names (like Tesla), building materials, or equipment types (such as heat pumps).

<aside> Note: The search system currently does not account for typos or variations in terminology. Contractors may use different abbreviations (like "SFR" instead of "single family residence"), so keep this in mind when searching.

</aside>

Permit Statuses Explained

  • What do the different permit statuses mean?

    Permits in the Shovels dashboard can have the following statuses:

    • Applied For: The permit is in review
    • Active: The permit has been approved
    • Finaled: The permit is fully completed
    • Inactive: No date changes have been observed for this permit in a while

    For more detailed information on permit statuses, check out the blog post on the Shovels website.

Contractor Search

How can I find contractors?

You can search for contractors based on the types of permits they've pulled. The contractor search provides:

  • Business names
  • Total lifetime number of permits pulled
  • Detailed contractor information (for full subscribers)
  • Contact information
  • History of permits they've pulled

<aside> Important: Not all permits include contractor information. Some jurisdictions don't require contractors to provide their contact details.

</aside>

Permit Search

What information is available about permits?

When viewing permits, you'll see:

  • Permit status
  • Address (when available)
  • Detailed information about the work being done

Note that some permits may not have addresses. This is common with new construction permits where an address hasn't been assigned yet.

Data Export Options

Can I export the data?

Paying customers can download search results as CSV files. This feature is not available on trial accounts.

Additional Resources

Where can I learn more about the data available?

Check out the Data Dictionary on the Shovels website. It provides information on:

  • Data schema
  • Permit categories
  • Contractor information
  • Additional appended data points

Contact Information

For support questions: support@shovels.ai

For sales inquiries about API access, upgrading Shovels Online, or enterprise products: sales@shovels.ai

Article title: What if I need to search for permits in a specific state?
Article body:
Use the 2-letter state abbreviation for the geo_ID. Examples: California = CA, Texas = TX, Florida = FL

Access our API documentation for further details.

Article title: Is there a way to automate API calls?
Article body:
Yes, developers can automate API calls by integrating the API into their applications using programming languages like Python, as demonstrated by generating code snippets from the API documentation.

Access our API documentation for further details.

Article title: What is an API endpoint?
Article body:
An API endpoint is a specific URL that represents a particular function or query within the API. Each endpoint is designed to answer a specific question or request related to the data.

Access our API documentation for further details.

Access our API documentation for further details.

Article title: How many permits can I retrieve in one API call?
Article subtitle: You can retrieve 100 permits per API call
Article body:
You can retrieve a maximum of 100 permits per API call. If you need more data, you will have to paginate through the results using the next cursor value provided in the response.

Access our API documentation for further details.

Article title: What are query parameters?
Article body:
Query parameters are additional details you can include in your API request to specify the data you want to retrieve. They help refine your query to get more relevant results.

Access our API documentation for further details.

Article title: What is the rate limit for API calls?

Article body:
It depends on the API plan you're on. API Starter gives you 10,000 calls per month. Shovels also has additional tiers with higher limits, feel free to contact us for more details.

Article title: How can I find the Geo ID for a specific address?
Article body:
You can find the Geo ID for a specific address by using the 'search addresses' endpoint in the API, which will return the geo_id associated with that address.

Access our API documentation for further details.

Article title: What does a 422 error mean when making an API call?
Article subtitle: A 422 means you are missing a parameter
Article body:
A 422 error indicates that there is a missing required parameter in your API request. For example, if you forget to include the GEOID when querying permits, you will receive this error. The JSON output will help identify what is missing.

Access our API documentation for further details.

Article title: How can I tell if my API request was successful?
Article body:
A successful API request will return a 200 status code along with the requested data. If there are issues, you will receive an error code indicating the problem.

Access our API documentation for further details.

Article title: What happens if I exceed my API call limit?
Article subtitle: You must wait until your next billing cycle
Article body:
If you exceed your API call limit, you will not be able to make additional requests until your limit resets, which typically occurs at the start of the next billing cycle.

Access our API documentation for further details.

Article title: What is the difference between path parameters and query parameters?
Article body:
Path parameters are included in the URL path of the API request and are used to specify a particular resource, while query parameters are added to the URL to filter or refine the results of the request.

Access our API documentation for further details.

Article title: How do I access my API key?
Article subtitle: To access your API key, login to your Shovels account and go to the Accounts section
Article body:
You can access your API key by logging into your account on the Shovels platform and navigating to the Accounts section where the API key is displayed.

Access our API documentation for further details.

Article title: How does the deduplication process for the CONTRACTOR_ID work?
Article subtitle: Are contractor IDs deduplicated across different states?
Article body: We assign a unique contractor_ID to any contractor we see in our system, and work very hard to make sure this contractor_ID is deduplicated and a unique ID for the contractors that we collect from the permits. In our permits table, we include the contractor_ID whenever there is an associated contractor. If we believe a unique contractor with a unique contractor_ID is associated with a larger group or parent company (e.g. if we see a local plumber, and believe they are a local branch of a regional plumber), we will also associate that contractor_ID with a contractor group_ID. We do this per state, which means the same contractor ID will not appear across different states. For example, if ABC Plumbing Inc does business in both CA and AZ, it will have 2 unique contractor_IDs. However we are working on creating a national contractor ID, check our blog for latest announcements!

Article title: Understanding the Difference Between 'Unknown' and 'None' Permit Statuses
Article body:
Summary: This article explains the difference between 'Unknown' and 'None' permit statuses as they relate to permit tracking.

Understanding Permit Statuses

In the context of permit tracking, various statuses are used to indicate the progress of a permit. Common statuses include "in_review," "active," "final," and "inactive." These terms help track a permit's journey from filing to completion or discontinuation.

Difference Between 'Unknown' and 'None' Permit Status

  • Unknown: This status typically indicates that there is missing or unreported data regarding the permit. It suggests that the system does not have sufficient information to categorize the permit accurately.

  • None: This status may also reflect a lack of data, but it is often interpreted as the absence of any applicable permit status. It indicates that no permit has been issued or that the permit status is not applicable in the given context.

Both terms are not standard permit statuses found in available documentation, and their exact meanings may vary depending on the context or jurisdiction. For specific cases or further clarification, it may be beneficial to consult a human agent who can provide more detailed assistance.

Conclusion

Understanding the distinctions between 'Unknown' and 'None' permit statuses is essential for interpreting permit data accurately. If you encounter these statuses, they generally signify missing or unreported information, and further inquiry may be necessary for clarification.

Article title: How to Check Your Account's Auto-Renew Status and Troubleshoot Issues
Article body:
Summary: This article provides information on whether your account is set to auto-renew.

Checking Auto-Renew Status

To determine if your account is on auto-renew, follow these steps:

  1. Access Your Subscription Portal: Log in to your account and navigate to the subscription management section.
  2. Look for the Manage Button: There should be a "Manage" button that allows you to view and modify your subscription settings.
    • If the "Manage" button is disabled or greyed out, you may not have access to manage your subscription directly at that moment.
  3. Contact Support for Confirmation: If you are unable to access the management features, you can reach out to customer support for assistance. They can confirm whether your account is set to auto-renew.

Auto-Renew Confirmation

According to support interactions, if you have an active subscription, it is typically set to auto-renew. If you need confirmation about your specific account status, contacting customer support is recommended.

Troubleshooting Access Issues

  • If the "Manage" button is not functioning, it may be due to a recent platform upgrade. In such cases, refreshing the page after a few minutes may resolve the issue.
  • If the problem persists, contacting customer support will provide further assistance.

Conclusion

To check if your account is on auto-renew, access your subscription portal and look for the management options. If you encounter issues, customer support can confirm your auto-renew status and assist with any access problems.

Article body:

Article title: Accessing Resident Demographic Data via the Shovels API
Article subtitle: This article explains how to access resident data through the Shovels API, including the types of demographic information available and the process for retrieving it.
Article body:
The Shovels API supports access to resident data, which includes demographic features such as gender, age range, and income range. This data is compiled from multiple sources and validated using consensus and observation methodologies.

Available Resident Data

  • Demographic Features: The API provides access to various demographic attributes, including:
    • Gender
    • Age range
    • Income range
  • Data Access Requirements: To access resident data, common linkages such as name, address, and workplace must be established.

API Endpoints for Resident Data

While the primary focus of the Shovels API documentation is on permits and contractors, resident demographic data is available through specialized endpoints. The resident data can be accessed via:

  • Specialized Data Endpoints: These endpoints are part of Shovels' extended data products, including the Universal Schema and Consumer Attributes dataset.

How to Access Resident Data

  1. API Subscription: To access resident demographic data, you need a Shovels API subscription.
  2. Documentation Review: For detailed information on the available resident data fields and schema, refer to the Data Dictionary.
  3. Data Extraction: You can extract resident data using the appropriate API endpoints as outlined in the documentation. This includes using specific parameters to retrieve the desired datasets.

Limitations

  • The API does not provide individual resident data through the basic permit and contractor endpoints. Instead, it focuses on properties and contractors, aligning with how permit data is collected and published by local jurisdictions.
  • Instead, use the geo_id to access the residents from our residents endpoint.

Conclusion

Accessing resident data through the Shovels API is possible with a subscription and by utilizing specialized endpoints. For comprehensive details on the data available and how to retrieve it, users should refer to the Universal Schema documentation. If you have specific use cases or need further assistance, consider reaching out for additional support.

Article title: How to Search for Permits by Address Using API Endpoints
Article subtitle: This article explains how to search for permits associated with a specific address using the available API endpoints.
Article body:
To retrieve the permit history for a specific address, follow this two-step process:

Step 1: Get the Address's Geo ID

Use the Search Addresses endpoint with your target address. This returns the address's geo_id—a unique identifier you'll need for the next step.

Step 2: Search Permits Using the Geo ID

Use the Search Permits endpoint with the geo_id from Step 1, along with your desired date range.

Pro tip: The geo_id parameter is a unified geography filter. The same permit search works whether you pass in a state abbreviation (CA), a zip code (94103), or an individual address's geo_id. You're just swapping out the geography level.

Alternative: Use Shovels Online

For quick lookups without code, use the Location Search feature in Shovels Online to search by address directly.

Need Help?

  • Interactive API Playground – test queries in your browser
  • Contact Support

Article title: Exploring Features of the Shovels AI Free Trial: A Guide
Article subtitle: This article outlines the features and capabilities available during the free trial of Shovels Online web application.
Article body:
Features Available in the Free Trial

  1. Permit & Contractor Search Feature:

    • Users can access the permit and contractor search functionality (left hand side of user interface).

  2. Data Availability:

    • The free trial includes access to the last 12 months of permit & contractor data. Paying customers get access to all historical Shovels data (on average, 25+ years).
