The free trial of Shovels Online provides users with valuable tools for accessing and analyzing permit & contractor data, along with various filtering options to enhance their search experience. Users are encouraged to explore these features and provide feedback to help shape future improvements.

Article title: Permit Status Details
Article subtitle: Understanding Shovels Permit Statuses
Article body:
In the context of permit tracking, various statuses are used to indicate the lifecycle and progress of a permit from filing to completion or discontinuation. Common permit statuses include "in_review," "active," "final," and "inactive." These statuses help users understand where a permit stands in the overall process. These statuses follow a chronological progression in most cases. 

In the Shovels ecosystem, there are four statuses that permits can be in:

  • in_review: From the moment the permit is filed with the local jurisdiction, until it is approved. This is defined by the file_date object.
  • active: From the moment the permit is approved, until project completion or some other intermediate restriction. This is defined by the issue_date object.
  • final: When the permit is completed, and submitted back to the jurisdiction upon job completion. This is defined by the final_date object.
  • inactive: If any part of the process stalls or gets restricted from progression, then the permit status moves to inactive. Disqualifying reasons and reporting time will vary by jurisdiction and local regulation, but can include failing to meet project inspections, the permit may expire before completion or inactivity for more than 6 months (180 days), and many others.

Sometimes there are "unknown" and "none" permit statuses. There are various reasons this can happen, including variances in jurisdiction record keeping, lack of data, dates not provided, and more. The exact meanings of these statuses can vary depending on the context or jurisdiction in which they are used.

For more information on Shovels permit statuses, read Shovels 101: Permit Statuses

Article title: Tracking Permits for Major Industrial Projects: Key Metadata Explained
Article body:
Summary: This article explains how permits for major industrial projects are tracked and the type of information provided.

Tracking Permits for Major Industrial Projects

Yes, we track permits for major industrial projects. Our support includes providing detailed metadata about building permits. This metadata encompasses various aspects, including:

  • Dates: Important dates related to the permit process.
  • Descriptions: Information describing the nature of the permits.
  • Fees: Details regarding any associated costs.
  • Statuses: Current status updates on the permits.

However, it is important to note that we do not provide the actual permit documents or PDFs, such as engineering stamps or site plans. For more technical details, users can refer to our Data Dictionary and API schema for a comprehensive overview of the data we provide.

Conclusion

In summary, we offer robust support for tracking permits related to major industrial projects, focusing on essential metadata while excluding specific technical documents. For further details, users are encouraged to consult our Data Dictionary and API schema.

Article title: How to Download Building Permit Data to CSV for Analysis
Article body:
Summary: This article explains how to download building permit data to CSV for further analysis.

Downloading Results to CSV

To download building permit data to CSV for further analysis, follow these steps:

  1. Access Shovels Online: Navigate to the Shovels Online platform where you can explore building permit data.
  2. Select Geography: Choose a specific geography, such as a city or county, to view its profile. This profile includes various statistics, including permit approval and construction times.
  3. Locate Download Option: Once you have accessed the desired data, look for an option to download the results. This option typically allows you to export the data in CSV format.
  4. Download the CSV File: Click on the download option to save the data to your device in CSV format for further analysis.

Conclusion

Downloading building permit data to CSV is a straightforward process that enables you to conduct further analysis on the information. By following the steps outlined above, you can easily access and export the data you need.

Article title: Best Practices for Optimizing Responses with the Shovels API
Article body:
To optimize API responses when using the Shovels API, consider the following best practices:

Key Tips for Optimizing API Responses

  1. Use the Address Search API First:

    • Always start with the Address Search API to obtain a valid geo_id. This step ensures that you receive consistent and accurate results, even if the address format varies.

  2. Handle Errors Properly:

    • Be prepared to manage errors effectively. If you use an invalid geo_id, you will receive a 422 error. If the geo_id is valid but not linked to any property data, a 200 response will be returned with an empty result set. Ensure your application can handle both scenarios.

  3. Utilize Filters Efficiently:

    • The permit search endpoint allows the use of filters for parameters such as date and permit type. Applying these filters can help narrow down results and reduce the amount of unnecessary data returned.

  4. Check for Empty Result Sets:

    • Treat empty result sets as an indication that the address may not be in the system, rather than solely relying on error codes. This can help in understanding the response better.

Conclusion

By following these guidelines, you can enhance the efficiency and accuracy of your API interactions with the Shovels API. Implementing these practices will help ensure smoother operations and better management of API responses.

Article title: How to Request Manual Reports on the Shovels Platform
Article body:
Summary

This article explains how to manually run reports within the Shovels platform, including the current capabilities and options available for users.

Manual Report Generation

Currently, users can still request manual reports from the support team while the functionality for generating reports directly from the web app is being improved. If you need a specific report, you can reach out to support and provide details about the format and data you require.

Steps to Request a Manual Report

  1. Contact Support: Reach out to the Shovels support team via email (sales@shovels.ai), Contact Us form, or phone.
  2. Specify Your Needs: Clearly describe the type of report you need, including any specific data points or formats you want.
  3. Provide Examples: If possible, share an example of the report format you are looking for to help the support team create the report to your specifications.

Example Use Cases

  • If you need a list of solar permits for a specific company, such as Vivint or Solar City, mention this in your request.
  • If you require historical data beyond the standard limits available in the dashboard, indicate that you need an "all-time" history report.
Current Limitations
  • The web app currently allows users to access data only for the last 12 months unless manually adjusted by support.
  • There may be limits on the number of results that can be exported at one time, so it is advisable to request reports for smaller batches or specific filters.
Conclusion

While the ability to manually run reports is still available through support, users are encouraged to specify their needs clearly to ensure they receive the correct data. As the platform continues to evolve, improvements to report generation capabilities are expected in the future.

Article title: Troubleshooting a Greyed-Out "Apply Filters" Button: Steps to Resolve
Article body:
If the "Apply filters" button is greyed out, it typically indicates one of two issues related to the filters you have set. Here’s what you can do to resolve the problem:

Possible Reasons for the Greyed-Out Button

  1. Address/Filter Details Not Resolved:

    • The system requires a valid address or search parameter (such as a geo_id) to enable results. If the address or filters do not match what’s in the database, the button will remain inactive, and no results will appear.

  2. No Results for Filters:

    • If the information entered is correct but there are no permits that match your filters, the system will also return nothing, causing the "Apply filters" button to be greyed out.
Steps to Troubleshoot

  • Check Required Fields: Ensure that all required address fields are filled in accurately. This includes:

    • geolocation (such as state, county, city, jurisdiction, zip code or address)

  • Verify Dates and Geography: Make sure you have both date fields and a geographical area set. These are typically the first fields you encounter on the top left of the filter options.

  • Broaden Your Filters: If you are still encountering issues, try broadening your filters or double-checking the spelling and format of the information you have entered.

If you continue to experience difficulties or need assistance with a specific search, consider reaching out for further help.

Article title: Why do some permits not have addresses?
Article body: Address IDs are only assigned if physical addresses can be confirmed via internal and third-party databases. Permits for new construction are often submitted before official addresses exist or streets are named, so they naturally lack addresses.

Article title: Understanding Monthly Query Limits for the $599 API Subscription
Article body:
Summary

This article provides information on the number of queries that can be made monthly through the API subscription.

Monthly Query Limits

For the API subscription priced at $599 per month, users can make up to 10,000 requests each month.

Additional Information

  • Each individual API call can return a maximum of 100 records.
  • Usage is tracked within the app, and users can view their request usage in the profile settings. The usage counts are refreshed nightly.

Conclusion

With the $599 monthly API subscription, users have the capacity to make a substantial number of queries, allowing for extensive data retrieval and analysis. For more detailed usage tracking, users can access their profile settings within the application.

Article title: How to Check Project Completion and Inspection Status via Permits
Article body:
Determining Project Completion and Inspection Status from Permit Records

Overview

This article explains how to determine if a project was completed and passed inspection using permit records.

Checking Project Completion

To ascertain whether a project has been completed and passed inspection, you can refer to the permit status. The status will indicate if the project is "final," which signifies that all work has been completed and the project has passed inspection.

Additional Information

  • Permit records can provide various details about the project, but the availability of specific information, such as system size, may depend on what the jurisdiction includes in the permit description.
  • Historical permit records can be accessed, with some jurisdictions allowing searches back up to 25 years.

Conclusion

By checking the permit status for a "final" designation, you can confirm that a project has been completed and passed inspection. For further details or historical data, consult the relevant permit records as needed.

Article title: How to Request Sample Records for Data Verification
Article body:
Sample Records for Data Verification

Summary: This article provides information on obtaining sample records to verify if the data fits your needs.

Requesting Sample Records

If you are interested in verifying data for a specific use case, you can request sample records. Here’s how you can do this:

  1. Specify Your Use Case: Clearly outline the type of data you need. For example, you might request recent permits for commercial properties in a specific location, such as California, and specify the types of properties you are interested in (e.g., motels, hotels, restaurants).

  2. Contact Support: Reach out to customer support with your request. You can ask for a couple of sample records to assess if the data meets your requirements.

  3. API Option: If you are considering using the API, you can also request sample records through the API subscription. This allows you to explore the data yourself.

Example Request

When making your request, you might say:

  • "Could I have a couple of sample records for my use case so I can verify if it fits my needs?"

Conclusion

Obtaining sample records is a straightforward process that involves specifying your data needs and contacting support. Whether you choose to receive these samples through direct support or via the API, ensure that you clearly communicate your requirements to facilitate a quick response.
